Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Towards Predicting Fire Suppression Performance: Quantifying Fire-Spray Interactions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Strategically delivering water to burning commodities is one of the most effective and robust means of suppressing accidental fires. Because of its unparalleled performance and versatility, water-based fire suppression is used extensively. Although the basic cooling (gas and surface) and O2 displacement mechanisms associated with water-based fire suppression are easy to identify, developing detailed models to support fire suppression analysis remains a challenge because of the turbulence, stochastic process, separation of scales, and complex chemistry important to the physical processes governing suppression performance. The enormous complexity of the fire suppression problem is daunting. As such, progress to establish analytical capabilities for evaluating suppression performance has been slow. The absence of this analytical capability has locked the fire safety industry into a costly empirical spiral inhibiting innovation. Dispersed spray interactions (with hot gases, flames, and thermal radiation) and delivered spray interactions (with burning and heated target surfaces) are important in determining fire suppression performance. These dispersed and delivered spray interactions represent rich kinematic, thermal, and chemical processes worthy of exploration. Canonical laboratory-scale and full-scale configurations will be used to isolate and evaluate these phenomena through parallel experimental and numerical activities. Advanced spray characterization and flow diagnostics will be employed to gain insight into local suppression phenomena (useful for model formulation) while simultaneously measuring relevant integral quantities (useful for model validation). Spray transport, extinction, and radiation modeling techniques will be explored and developed for application to large-scale turbulent multi-phase reacting flows (i.e. fire) based on the corresponding canonical experiments. This research offers a comprehensive foundation for validating suppression performance including detailed canonical experiments, well-instrumented full-scale tests relevant to industry, and harmonized analysis.

Water-based fire suppression systems (e.g. sprinklers, water mists, hose streams) represent truly ubiquitous forms of engineering used for life safety and infrastructure protection. The underlying suppression technology is anchored largely in phenomenological observations, empiricism, and qualification tests. The University of Maryland Fire Protection Engineering Department has partnered with industry leaders in an ambitious effort to perform the focused experiments and model development required to equip computational based modeling tools used in fire safety analysis with validated models enabling a major step forward in CFD based evaluation of fire suppression performance. This capability will equip engineers with tools required for performance based fire suppression analysis and design perhaps leading to new technologies and engineering practices for life safety and infrastructure protection. The effort would produce 5 Ph.D. students with expertise in fire suppression and close connections with industry while providing numerous undergraduate research opportunities. This effort would also support an annual fire suppression modeling workshop hosted by UM providing a forum for research advances, industry challenges, and new engineering approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The general objective of this research program is to develop the scientific knowledge and the advanced engineering methods required to characterize the performance of water-based fire suppression systems. Water-based systems have emerged as an effective engineering design solution to the problem of protecting people and property against fire risk in buildings. The specific objectives of this research program are to study the atomization of the initial liquid water jet and the formation of a water spray as well as the subsequent interactions of the water spray with the fire room gas-phase processes, including interactions with flow, combustion and thermal radiation.

The present NSF-funded research project has supported the development of two new laboratory-scale experimental configurations: a first configuration aimed at characterizing the injection and atomization processes as well as the early liquid water spray dynamics in the vicinity of a sprinkler head; and a second configuration aimed at characterizing the response of a buoyancy-driven turbulent flame to an inert gas or a water spray, including the decrease in combustion intensity and possible partial/total flame quenching as well as the corresponding decrease in radiation intensity. The present research project has also supported the development of new physical models and algorithms to describe spray initialization and flame extinction in existing fire simulation software based on Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD). CFD simulation software is routinely used by practicing fire protection engineers in projects aimed at performance-based design of fire suppression systems.

The main outcomes of the present research project are: the experimental characterization of the initial water spray (i.e., statistical distributions of drop sizes, velocities and number densities) produced by canonical sprinklers; the numerical characterization of the initial sprinkler spray through an atomization model that can be used as a boundary condition model in CFD simulation software; the experimental characterization of the dispersion of water droplets (i.e., spatial variations of liquid water fluxes) in the presence of a plume; the experimental characterization of the response of a turbulent fire to oxygen starvation through inert gas dilution and evaporative cooling through interaction with a water mist (i.e., measurements of the global combustion efficiency and radiative loss fraction as well as measurements of local flame temperatures); the numerical characterization of flame extinction due to oxygen starvation and/or evaporative cooling through a combustion model that can be used in existing CFD simulation software for fire applications.

The present research project is expected to have profound scientific and engineering impact. First, the formulation of a generic atomization model for sprinkler sprays may now be used by sprinkler manufacturers to inform the design and development of new sprinkler systems. Second, the development and validation of new fire suppression capabilities for existing CFD simulation software may be used by fire protection engineers to design more reliable and cost-effective fire suppression systems and strategies. Third, the new experimental configuration for turbulent flame extinction developed in this program has been recognized for its value, quality and uniqueness and has already been adopted by a group of leading fire researchers representing the international fire science community as a reference target experiment for CFD model validation (https://iafss.org/macfp/).

Overall, the present NSF-funded research project has produced new knowledge and new engineering tools for the establishment of a scientific basis in the design of water-based fire suppression systems.
